@_WillPenning @tapas321 Testing in schools (or at home before going to school) has been scrapped, apart from in schools/units for pupils with special educational needs/disabilities and "Alternative Provision" for children who cannot attend mainstream schools. For details, see:
https://t.co/75BGm9HbPV

@AlastairGrant4 @tapas321 This is great, thankyou for this Alastair. 

Are you aware if testing in schools is currently continuing or has that also been scrapped. It would be interesting to see if there is a rise again as schools return from half term.
@tapas321 @AlastairGrant4 @_WillPenning ONS has gone back to (weekly?) Friday updates apparently.

@AlastairGrant4 Pillar 1 isn’t particularly reflective of infection in the community IMO because it will always have age stratification will almost always low child numbers, but yes, that should be the barometer for picking up variants.

@AlastairGrant4 @_WillPenning ONS is pretty good and pretty speedy now we have Wednesday’s report. We only really got a precise dashboard reading by day 4 due to late results. Today’s ONS report will produce data up till 5 days ago. Decent granularity of that data will be reported on Friday.

Week on week, the pillar 1 data show the same rapid fall in teenagers as the full data, with slower falls elsewhere. Numbers among the over 80's are reducing only very slowly, which may explain why admissions are not down as much as cases https://t.co/QhUBgyLC5b

So what are the Pillar 1 data telling us at the moment? Rates reflect both numbers of tests at age and the pprotion postive. They are low among children but roughly constant among adults < 70
Rates are highest among the elderly, but there is also a peak in very young children https://t.co/FzLjs7vG8D
But most importantly, if a future new variant leads to increased risk of serious illness, those with significant symptoms will be funnelled into pillar 1 when they present at A&E or are admitted.
